teaching_points: Propofol induction dose based on lean body weight (LBW) to avoid overdosing
Succinylcholine dosed on total body weight (TBW) due to increased pseudocholinesterase
Maintenance volatile agents and opioids based on ideal body weight (IBW)
Increased volume of distribution for lipophilic drugs in obesity
Obesity increases cardiac output and hepatic blood flow affecting drug clearance
STOP-Bang score >5 indicates high OSA risk - requires postoperative monitoring
BMI 58 with CPAP use confirms severe OSA diagnosis
Difficult mask ventilation predicted by BMI >30, age >55, beard, edentulous
OSA increases risk of perioperative cardiovascular complications 2-3 fold
Preoperative CPAP optimization reduces postoperative respiratory complications
Ramped positioning (head elevated 25-30 degrees) aligns ear to sternal notch for optimal intubation
Preoxygenation critical - FRC reduced 50% in morbid obesity, desaturation occurs rapidly
Awake fiberoptic intubation considered if Mallampati IV, limited mouth opening, or neck circumference >60cm
Neuraxial anesthesia reduces pulmonary complications and opioid requirements
Reverse Trendelenburg 15-20 degrees improves respiratory mechanics during surgery
Avoid excessive opioids - use multimodal analgesia with regional techniques

clinical_challenges: Positioning challenges and pressure injury risk
monitoring_needs: Arterial line for frequent blood gases and hemodynamic monitoring
Capnography essential - early warning of respiratory depression
Nerve stimulator for neuromuscular blockade monitoring
anesthetic_considerations: Extended preoxygenation (8 vital capacity breaths or 3 minutes)
Multimodal analgesia (local infiltration, IV acetaminophen, ketorolac)
Regional anesthesia when possible (TAP block for open procedures)
Awake extubation with full reversal and return of airway reflexes
Enhanced recovery protocol with early mobilization

teaching_points: BMI 62 (super morbid obesity) requires careful weight-based dosing calculations
Remifentanil preferred opioid - dosed on IBW, no accumulation
Neuromuscular blockers: rocuronium and sugammadex dosed on IBW
PEEP 10-15 cmH2O prevents atelectasis in obesity
Protective lung ventilation: tidal volume 6-8 mL/kg IBW, not TBW
Obesity hypoventilation syndrome increases pulmonary hypertension and right heart strain
Difficult IV access requires ultrasound guidance - prepare early
Hypertension in obesity often resistant - continue home antihypertensives
Increased risk of MACE with BMI >40 and multiple comorbidities = ASA IV
Consider preoperative cardiology consultation for EF assessment
Pneumoperitoneum further reduces FRC and increases peak airway pressures
Reverse Trendelenburg improves ventilation but decreases venous return
Avoid excessive insufflation pressure (keep <15 mmHg)
Monitor for CO2 absorption - can cause hypercarbia and acidosis
PEEP recruitment maneuvers after desufflation improve oxygenation

clinical_challenges: High risk for postoperative respiratory failure
monitoring_needs: Standard ASA monitors with arterial line
anesthetic_considerations: Early arterial line placement for ABG monitoring
Aggressive DVT prophylaxis (sequential compression devices + pharmacologic)

teaching_points: Asthma + obesity = increased perioperative bronchospasm risk
Preoperative beta-agonist and corticosteroid optimization essential
Depression medications may interact with anesthetics (SSRIs and MAO-I)
Avoid desflurane - highest airway irritant among volatile agents
Consider deep extubation vs awake based on airway anatomy
Obesity and bariatric surgery = very high aspiration risk
Aspiration prophylaxis: H2-blocker + metoclopramide + sodium citrate
NPO guidelines strictly enforced (8 hours solids, 2 hours clear liquids)
Rapid sequence intubation technique for gastric bypass patients
Head-up positioning 30 degrees reduces gastric pressure and aspiration risk
SSRIs increase bleeding risk - consider effect on surgical hemostasis
Antidepressants may prolong QTc - avoid droperidol and ondansetron
Continue antidepressants perioperatively to prevent withdrawal
Anxiety increases sympathetic response - consider anxiolytic premedication

anesthetic_considerations: Deep extubation if excellent airway anatomy, otherwise awake

teaching_points: Obesity cardiomyopathy with reduced EF = high cardiac risk
Heart failure + OSA = biventricular dysfunction common
Maintain preload - avoid excessive PEEP reducing venous return
Goal-directed fluid therapy prevents both overload and inadequate perfusion
Positive pressure ventilation decreases afterload (beneficial in HFrEF)
RCRI score ≥3 (heart failure + high-risk surgery) = very high MACE risk
Cardiology consultation for optimization essential
Beta-blockers continued perioperatively
BNP/troponin monitoring perioperatively for myocardial injury
Consider ICU monitoring postoperatively
Etomidate preferred for induction - minimal cardiac depression
Arterial line pre-induction for beat-to-beat BP monitoring
Consider central venous access for vasopressor administration
Avoid large fluid boluses - use 250mL aliquots with assessment
Have norepinephrine or phenylephrine infusion ready

anesthetic_considerations: Goal-directed fluid therapy with dynamic indices
Minimize myocardial depression - avoid high-dose volatile agents
Lung protective ventilation with moderate PEEP

teaching_points: NAFLD common in obesity - assess liver function preoperatively
Fatty liver may affect drug metabolism (reduced clearance)
GERD universally present in obesity - highest aspiration risk
H. pylori testing often performed before bariatric surgery
Avoid hepatotoxic drugs (prolonged high-dose acetaminophen)
GERD + obesity = aspiration prophylaxis mandatory (triple therapy)
Proton pump inhibitor night before and morning of surgery
RSI with cricoid pressure (Sellick maneuver) controversial but commonly used
Ramped position for RSI improves success and safety
Avoid mask ventilation before intubation in true RSI
Fatty infiltration may reduce hepatic clearance capacity
NAFLD rarely causes significant coagulopathy unless cirrhotic
Most anesthetic drugs well-tolerated in NAFLD
Avoid prolonged infusions of drugs with hepatic metabolism

monitoring_needs: Consider arterial line for longer procedures

teaching_points: BMI 65 = super morbid obesity with extreme physiologic derangements
Duodenal switch = longest, most complex bariatric procedure (3-5 hours)
Multiple comorbidities (diabetes, hypertension) = ASA IV classification
High risk for postoperative complications including leak and VTE
Preoperative weight loss and optimization critical
Prolonged surgery increases VTE risk exponentially in obesity
Sequential compression devices applied before induction
Pharmacologic prophylaxis with higher doses (enoxaparin 40mg BID)
Hypothermia prevention critical (forced air warming, fluid warmers)
Glucose monitoring every 1-2 hours in diabetics
Large body surface area increases heat loss
Hypothermia increases infection risk and coagulopathy
Goal-directed fluid therapy prevents overload
Obesity increases insensible losses
PCOS associated with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome
Pre-diabetes requires glucose monitoring perioperatively
Young age protective but obesity still confers significant risk
Fertility goals post-surgery require pregnancy planning (wait 12-18 months)
PCOS increases risk of OSA even at younger age
ERAS protocols reduce complications in bariatric surgery
Early feeding (clear liquids at 2 hours) safe and beneficial
Minimize opioids - multimodal analgesia protocol
Early ambulation (within 4 hours) prevents VTE and improves outcomes
Dexamethasone reduces PONV (common in young females and laparoscopy)
Insulin resistance present even without overt diabetes
Stress response amplifies hyperglycemia
Target glucose <180 mg/dL perioperatively
Pre-diabetes typically managed without insulin

monitoring_needs: Consider arterial line for longer cases

teaching_points: Revision surgery has higher complication rates than primary bariatric surgery
Band removal with conversion to bypass/sleeve common for band complications
Difficult anatomy from adhesions increases operative time and blood loss
Previous band may have caused esophageal dilation - aspiration risk higher
Nutritional deficiencies common after failed bariatric procedures
Adhesiolysis increases surgical time unpredictably
Higher conversion to open surgery rate in revisions
Blood loss risk higher - type and screen mandatory
Previous pneumoperitoneum may have caused adhesions affecting lung expansion
Pain scores often higher in revision surgery
Chronic joint pain may indicate chronic opioid use
Opioid tolerance requires higher doses for analgesia
Multimodal approach critical to minimize opioid escalation
Regional techniques (TAP block) particularly beneficial
OSA + opioids = very high respiratory depression risk

anesthetic_considerations: Prepare for longer surgery than scheduled
Extra warming measures for prolonged case
Pain management consultation if chronic opioid use

teaching_points: Hypothyroidism increases anesthetic sensitivity - reduce doses 20-30%
Continue levothyroxine perioperatively (give morning of surgery)
Hypothyroidism slows drug metabolism and increases myocardial depression risk
Asthma + obesity increases bronchospasm risk significantly
OSA more common with hypothyroidism
Hypothyroidism may cause macroglossia affecting airway
Obesity + asthma + hypothyroidism = complex airway management
Careful preoxygenation and positioning critical
Avoid drugs that release histamine in asthmatic patients
Slower emergence expected with hypothyroidism
Hypothyroidism decreases MAC requirements
Myocardial contractility reduced - careful with cardiodepressant drugs
Delayed gastric emptying increases aspiration risk
Hypothermia risk increased
Chronic opioid use creates tolerance requiring higher perioperative doses
Bariatric surgery + opioid dependence = very difficult pain management
Multimodal analgesia critical to avoid excessive opioid dosing
OSA + chronic opioids = extreme respiratory depression risk
Preoperative pain management consultation recommended
TAP block provides excellent analgesia for bariatric surgery
Ketamine infusion (0.1-0.2 mg/kg/hr) reduces opioid requirements
Continue baseline opioids perioperatively to prevent withdrawal
Gabapentin 600-1200mg preoperatively reduces opioid needs 30-40%
IV acetaminophen and ketorolac as baseline non-opioid analgesia
Regional anesthesia may reduce central sensitization
Opioid tolerance due to receptor downregulation and desensitization
Cross-tolerance exists between opioid classes
Remifentanil useful intraoperatively - no accumulation despite tolerance
Avoid abrupt discontinuation - risk of hyperalgesia and withdrawal
Chronic opioids alter pain perception creating hyperalgesia

clinical_challenges: Morbid obesity with chronic opioid use
anesthetic_considerations: Minimize additional intraoperative opioids beyond baseline
No PCA - increased risk in OSA with opioid tolerance

teaching_points: CPP = MAP - ICP, maintain CPP >60-70 mmHg for adequate cerebral perfusion
Brain tumor causes mass effect increasing ICP
Cerebral autoregulation maintains constant blood flow between MAP 50-150 mmHg
Increased ICP shifts autoregulation curve rightward
Monroe-Kellie doctrine: skull is fixed volume - blood, brain, CSF compensate
MEPs and SSEPs monitor spinal cord and motor pathway integrity
Avoid neuromuscular blockade during MEP monitoring - interferes with readings
Brain relaxation: hyperventilation to PaCO2 30-35 mmHg, mannitol 0.25-1 g/kg, head-up 15-30 degrees
Propofol and volatile agents at <1 MAC compatible with neuromonitoring
Total IV anesthesia (TIVA) preferred for reliable MEP/SSEP monitoring
Continue antiepileptic drugs perioperatively to prevent seizures
Phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital induce hepatic enzymes affecting drug metabolism
Many AEDs cause thrombocytopenia - check platelet count
Seizure precautions: bite block, padding, suction ready
Brain tumor patients at high seizure risk perioperatively

monitoring_needs: Central venous access for mannitol/hypertonic saline
anesthetic_considerations: TIVA with propofol and remifentanil preferred
Avoid nitrous oxide (expands air if pneumocephalus)
Hyperventilation for brain relaxation (avoid excessive <30 mmHg)
Elevate head of bed 30 degrees postoperatively

teaching_points: Cerebral aneurysm rupture risk increases with BP, transmural pressure, and aneurysm size
Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) causes cerebral vasospasm 4-14 days post-rupture
BP control critical: too high = rupture risk, too low = ischemia
Goal SBP 100-140 mmHg before clipping (prevents rupture)
After clipping can allow higher BP (SBP 140-160) to prevent vasospasm
Hypertension chronic changes make brain vulnerable to hypotension
Temporary clipping during dissection requires neuroprotection strategies
Burst suppression with propofol or barbiturates reduces CMRO2
Mild hypothermia (33-35°C) neuroprotective but increases complications
Induced hypotension (MAP 50-60) during clipping reduces aneurysm tension
Avoid hypotension if patient has SAH (vasospasm risk)
Nimodipine 60mg Q4H prevents vasospasm after SAH
Uncontrolled hypertension = ASA IV for aneurysm surgery
Smooth induction critical - avoid hypertensive response to laryngoscopy
Remifentanil infusion blunts sympathetic surge
Have esmolol and nicardipine ready for BP control
Intubation under deep anesthesia prevents hypertension and rupture

monitoring_needs: EEG for burst suppression if needed
anesthetic_considerations: Arterial line awake or with gentle sedation
Induced hypotension during clipping if requested

teaching_points: Prone positioning increases intraocular pressure - risk of vision loss
Eyes must be checked frequently and free from pressure
Chest rolls allow abdominal expansion - reduces IVC compression
Reduce bleeding by minimizing venous pressure (avoid abdominal compression)
Jackson table or Wilson frame commonly used for spine surgery
Position arms <90 degrees abduction to prevent brachial plexus injury
Diabetes causes peripheral neuropathy - increased nerve injury risk
Document preoperative neurologic deficits
Meticulous padding of pressure points critical
Spinal stenosis may cause baseline neurologic symptoms
Postoperative neurologic exam essential
Laminectomy typically low blood loss (<500 mL)
Multi-level procedures increase blood loss significantly
Minimize venous pressure to reduce epidural bleeding
Cell saver available for extensive procedures
Tranexamic acid may reduce blood loss

monitoring_needs: Arterial line for longer multi-level cases
Nerve stimulator if MEPs not used
anesthetic_considerations: Careful prone positioning with eye protection
Chest rolls to allow abdominal expansion
Consider controlled hypotension (MAP 65-75) to reduce bleeding
Multimodal analgesia (IV acetaminophen, ketorolac if appropriate)

teaching_points: AVM = abnormal connection between arteries and veins without capillary bed
High-flow AVM causes vascular steal from surrounding brain
Rupture risk 2-4% per year causing hemorrhage
Normal perfusion pressure breakthrough theory after AVM resection
Surrounding brain chronically hypoperfused adapts to low pressure
Massive hemorrhage possible during AVM resection
Large bore IV access x2 mandatory
Cross-matched blood immediately available (4-6 units)
Controlled hypotension (MAP 60-70) during dissection reduces bleeding
After resection, maintain normotension to prevent breakthrough bleeding
Cell saver contraindicated if tumor cells present, ok for AVM
Young healthy patient otherwise = better outcome
Migraines common with AVM - may worsen postoperatively
PONV prophylaxis important (young female = high risk)
Postoperative seizure prophylaxis often given
Neurologic deficits possible from surgery

clinical_challenges: Young patient - good reserve but high expectations
monitoring_needs: Consider CVP or PA catheter for large AVMs
anesthetic_considerations: Postoperative CT scan to assess for hemorrhage

teaching_points: Pituitary adenoma causes hormonal imbalances - check cortisol, thyroid, growth hormone
Diabetes insipidus (DI) common postoperatively from posterior pituitary injury
DI causes massive diuresis (>200-300 mL/hr) and hypernatremia
Adrenal insufficiency possible - stress dose steroids if suspected
Visual field deficits common - optic chiasm compression
Transsphenoidal approach via nose - shared airway with surgeon
Throat pack placed to prevent blood aspiration
Nasal decongestion with cocaine or oxymetazoline reduces bleeding
Avoid coughing on emergence - can cause bleeding and CSF leak
Smooth extubation critical - may need remifentanil or lidocaine
CSF leak risk postoperatively - avoid positive pressure ventilation
Monitor urine output hourly - DI causes polyuria
Replace urine output mL for mL if DI develops
Desmopressin (DDAVP) treats DI - 1-2 mcg IV
Monitor sodium frequently - hypernatremia from DI
Triphasic response possible: initial DI, then SIADH, then permanent DI

monitoring_needs: Arterial line for frequent blood gases and sodium
Serum and urine osmolality if DI suspected
anesthetic_considerations: Stress dose steroids if adrenal insufficiency suspected (hydrocortisone 100mg)
Avoid nitrous oxide (if air in sella)

teaching_points: Hydrocephalus = excessive CSF causing ventricular enlargement and increased ICP
Shunt malfunction causes acute ICP increase - headache, nausea, altered mental status
VP shunt drains CSF from ventricles to peritoneum
Shunt over-drainage can cause subdural hematoma
Multiple previous surgeries increase scar tissue and difficulty
Increased ICP at baseline - avoid further increases
Smooth induction - avoid coughing, straining, hypercapnia
Head-up positioning 15-30 degrees
Hyperventilation if acute ICP crisis (PaCO2 30-35)
Mannitol available for ICP control
Previous shunt infections common
Antibiotic prophylaxis critical (cefazolin or vancomycin)
Shunt revision typically short procedure (1-2 hours)
Low blood loss expected
Experienced patient - familiar with process

monitoring_needs: Arterial line usually not needed unless ICP very high
anesthetic_considerations: Smooth induction to avoid ICP increase
Propofol or thiopental for induction (decrease ICP)
Short procedure - plan for rapid awakening

teaching_points: Cervical myelopathy = spinal cord compression causing motor and sensory deficits
MEPs monitor motor pathways, SSEPs monitor sensory pathways
Avoid neuromuscular blockade during MEP monitoring
50% decrease in MEP amplitude or 10% increase in latency = warning
TIVA preferred (propofol/remifentanil) for stable monitoring
Volatile agents >0.5 MAC suppress MEPs significantly
Maintain MAP >80-90 mmHg to ensure spinal cord perfusion
Hypotension during instrumentation can cause spinal cord ischemia
Hypertension chronic changes shift autoregulation rightward
Wake-up test alternative if neuromonitoring unavailable or lost
Document preoperative neurologic deficits carefully
May be prone or supine depending on approach
Mayfield pins for head fixation - local anesthetic infiltration
Pin insertion can cause hypertension - treat with beta-blocker
Neck positioning critical - avoid hyperextension worsening myelopathy
Eyes protected and checked frequently in prone position

anesthetic_considerations: No paralysis after intubation (allow MEP monitoring)
Careful positioning to avoid worsening cord compression
If MEP changes: increase MAP, check positioning, reduce anesthetics
Smooth emergence for immediate neuro exam
Document motor and sensory function immediately

teaching_points: Chiari malformation = cerebellar tonsils herniate through foramen magnum
CSF flow obstruction causes hydrocephalus and syringomyelia
Decompression involves craniectomy and duraplasty to enlarge space
Prone or sitting position used for posterior fossa access
Sitting position has venous air embolism (VAE) risk 25-50%
VAE occurs when venous pressure at surgical site < atmospheric pressure
Sitting position creates negative venous pressure in head
VAE detected by: sudden decrease in ETCO2, hypotension, mill-wheel murmur
Precordial Doppler most sensitive monitor for VAE
Treatment: flood field with saline, lower head, Durant position, aspirate air from CVP
Young healthy patient otherwise = ASA II
Chronic headaches common symptom of Chiari
Extensive research by patient common - anxiety about surgery
Good outcomes expected with decompression
Headaches may worsen initially postoperatively before improving

monitoring_needs: Central venous catheter (for air aspiration if VAE)
anesthetic_considerations: Central line placed for air aspiration capability
If sitting: gradual positioning to avoid hypotension
Avoid nitrous oxide (expands air if VAE)
Watch for VAE signs (sudden ETCO2 drop, hypotension)
If VAE: flood field, lower head, aspirate CVP, support hemodynamics

surgical_type: Neurosurgical - Intramedullary Spinal Cord Tumor Resection

teaching_points: Intramedullary tumor inside spinal cord - highest complexity spine surgery
MEPs and SSEPs critical - any change may indicate permanent deficit
No neuromuscular blockade allowed after intubation
TIVA mandatory for stable monitoring (propofol/remifentanil)
Prone positioning for thoracic/lumbar cord access
Surgery may last 6-8 hours
Chronic opioid use creates tolerance - higher intraoperative requirements
Baseline opioid dose must be continued perioperatively
Multimodal analgesia critical despite opioid use
Acute pain service consultation recommended
Risk of hyperalgesia from chronic opioids
Hypothermia prevention critical in long cases
DVT prophylaxis with sequential compression devices
Pressure injury prevention - extra padding
Glucose monitoring if prolonged >4 hours
Staff breaks and relief planning for long case

anesthetic_considerations: TIVA with propofol and remifentanil only
Baseline opioid requirement calculated and continued
Maintain MAP >80-90 mmHg for spinal cord perfusion
Aggressive temperature management (forced air warmer, fluid warmer)
If MEP/SSEP changes: increase MAP, check position, decrease anesthetics, consider steroids
Plan for prolonged case - adequate supplies

teaching_points: Brain tumor patients at high seizure risk perioperatively
Multiple AEDs suggest refractory seizures - high risk
Continue all AEDs perioperatively to prevent status epilepticus
Enzyme-inducing AEDs (phenytoin, carbamazepine) increase drug metabolism
Check drug levels preoperatively if patient on AEDs chronically
Seizure precautions: bite block ready, padding, suction
Meningiomas are vascular tumors - significant bleeding risk
Often involve venous sinuses - major bleeding if injured
Preoperative embolization may reduce vascularity
Type and cross 2-4 units blood
Cell saver typically used
May require controlled hypotension to reduce bleeding
Phenytoin increases metabolism of NMB (require higher doses)
Phenytoin, carbamazepine induce CYP450 enzymes
AEDs may cause thrombocytopenia - check CBC
Some AEDs cause hyponatremia (carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine)
Valproic acid inhibits platelet function

anesthetic_considerations: Continue all AEDs perioperatively (IV formulations if NPO)
May need higher NMB doses due to enzyme induction
Controlled hypotension if requested by surgeon
Smooth emergence to avoid seizure trigger
